column18: Students come to class with the experience of their own observations, with knowledge acquired from their parents, facts learned from books, skills obtained from their previous teachers and other sources. How accurate were students' observations, how correct were their teachers' conclusions? How ready are your students for new experiences? "I saw it with my own eyes!" is often the students' strongest proof. But do the students interpret correctly what they see? The very concept that it is better to see once rather than to hear a dozen times is not always correct. Things are not always what they seem. Do we always see when we look? How to see the essence in the things we watch? How not to take for granted things assumed to be obvious. This all deserves to be discussed to improve our influence on the students' world outlook. What do you think? Opinions will be appreciated

column2: Best Practices for Teaching With Technology
column5: Innovative Interactive Lecture Demonstrations Using Wireless Force Sensors.
column15: Garett W Yoder, Eastern Kentucky University
column18: Interactive demonstrations are a powerful new tool to help instructors bring state-of-the-art teaching pedagogies into the college-level introductory physics classroom. We have used the new technology of Vernier's Wireless Dynamics Sensor System (WDSS) to develop three new interactive demonstrations for the first-semester introductory physics (calculus-based or algebra-based) classroom. These three are the Force Board, to demonstrate the vector nature of forces, addition of vectors and the 1st condition of equilibrium; the Torque Bar, to demonstrate the Torque and the 2nd condition for equilibrium; and the Circular Motion Platform (to demonstrate/discover the nature of the acceleration for a object exhibiting uniform circular motion.) With the force sensors, all three of these are easy to set up and use in any classroom or laboratory situation and allow more instructors to utilize the technique of interactive demonstrations.

column5: Physics Education in Brazil
column15: Marco A Moreira, Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul
column18: Physics is a required subject in Brazilian schools. However, the number of classes per week is just one or two and it is usually taught as training for the university entrance examination, stimulating rote learning. Teachers are prepared in a specially designed four-year college course, but there few people interested in it because it is demanding and being a physics teacher means, in practice, teaching up to 40 or 50 classes per week, at different schools, and having hundreds of students. There is no national association of physics teachers, but the Brazilian Society of Physics organizes national meetings and publishes a journal on physics education. Recently, Brazilian universities began to offer professional master's degrees in science education, some of them in physics education, designed for high school teachers. It is too early to evaluate this action but it looks promising to improve physics education in Brazil.

column2: PER: Problem Solving in Lecture and Lab
column5: The Specificity Effect: Separating Efficiency from Innovation in Learning Physics
column17: Brian H. Ross, Jose P. Mestre
column18: When students learn a new physics principle, that principle can become bound up with salient features of the example(s) in which the principle was instantiated. Rather than suggest this specificity effect is a difficulty that needs to be overcome, we suggest that it is an efficient way to solve certain types of physics problems. Even expert problem-solvers use problem surface features to cue relevant principled knowledge. The specificity effect becomes a difficulty when students are unable or unwilling to use the resources they have to consciously evaluate and self-assess their work in progress, in other words, to innovate. In this talk we will try to disentangle the ideas of innovation and efficiency in learning physics and discuss the implications of the specificity effect for what our physics students learn and how they learn it.

column5: Attracting Girls to Physics and Science Classes
column15: Catherine A Massey, Las Cruces High School
column18: The high school classroom is a good place to encourage more participation by girls and minorities in physics and other sciences. This talk will report on similarities and differences among countries in approaches and success in getting girls interested in the "hard sciences" in high school. Some successful strategies have included summer science camps for girls, the presence of female role models and supportive male teachers, classrooms that spark curiosity and provide prescriptive, informational feedback and positive images of women in scientific careers. Being supportive of girls and minorities and showing students that their abilities can improve over time with work are also helpful. Since this symposium is joint with AAPT, having the views of a high school teacher will appeal to a broad audience and translate the ideas into lessons for teachers, curriculum developers, text writers, parents, and those organizing enrichment activities aimed toward attracting girls to science.

column2: Current Directions in Materials Research: Graduate Students Talk to Teachers
column5: Graduate Students Discuss their Research at the Advanced Photon Source
column15: Carlo U Segre, Illinois Institute of Technology
column18: The Advanced Photon Source (APS) at Argonne National Laboratory is the premiere structural tool for materials science and physics research in the United States. In this session, we will provide attendees with a flavor for the research being conducted at the APS by giving them an opportunity to hear directly from four graduate students whose research takes advantage of this unique instrument.

column5: Teaching Electric Circuits in First-Year Undergraduate Laboratories
column15: David Smith, Castel, Dublin City University
column18: We present the development, implementation and evaluation of electric circuits curriculum for first-year undergraduate nonphysics students in an Irish University. A framework of guided inquiry is used, which focuses on the understanding of students and their ability to conceptualize physics. The constraints imposed by the first-year undergraduate laboratories required that we focused on key elements and that the curriculum was efficient in conveying the relevant concepts. The laboratories commenced in February 2008 and continued for three successive weeks. Pre-test data was collected through an online survey and post-test data was collected through two in-class exams. The preliminary analysis of this data has highlighted some significant student misconceptions, particularly in relation to current; it also highlights considerable improvements in student understanding on completion of the curriculum. This presentation will highlight some of the key findings from the data and will also discuss the approach in developing the curriculum.
column19: Dr. Paul van Kampen, Membership No. 66000

column5: Photonics: Assessing Diverse Students using Self-Instructional Video in Optics
column17: Joyce P. Hilliard-Clark, John C. Bedward, Joy C. Clark, Kimberly R. Smalls-McDougal
column18: Imhotep Academy Photonics program address the question of "how to integrate scientific content, student encouragement and parental support to engage minority high school students in physics an area of a national need?" African-American students do not take advanced mathematics and science courses, especially physics, in high school. We measured the instructional impact of a self-instructional video and traditional face-to-face lessons on diverse learners' conceptual understanding of optical physics, mathematics, and computer programming. Thirty-four high school students from 10 N.C. counties participate in 300 hours of inquiry-based optics, laser technology, investigations and externships through the National Science Foundation (NSF) Information Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) Photonics Leaders Program. Upon successful completion, students earn scholarship stipends and are equipped with skills for higher education and the global workplace. One hundred percent of the students attend a four-year university and 80% of the students have a science and mathematics major.

column2: Best Practices in Recruiting and Retaining Women and Minorities in Physics
column5: Challenging Diverse Female Students to Pursue STEM Careers
column17: Pamela O. Gilchrist, John Bedward, Joy C. Clark, Kimberly C. Smalls-McDougal
column18: Historical data indicates African Americans do not take advanced mathematics and science courses, especially physics, in high school. Therefore, we are using a variety of strategies for providing instruction in leadership, experimentation, research writing, communications, and scientific presentation to work with students, families, and teachers in promoting selection of and academic achievement in challenging science and physics courses. Seventy-five African American students with more than 56% being females are participating in year-round Photonics programs at The Science House on NC State University's Centennial Campus. Students from 16 counties in North Carolina learn about fiber optics, communications, and the properties of light. Imhotep Academy Photonics programs address the question of how to integrate scientific content, student encouragement, and parental support to engage minority high school students to experience success in Science, Engineering, Technology and Mathematics STEM areas of national need.

column5: Engaging Ethics in the Physics Curriculum: Theory, Practice and Assessment?
column15: Jean-Francois S Van Huele, Brigham Young University
column18: I report on my experience with ethics teaching in the physics curriculum from introductory undergraduate classes to graduate seminars. What works and what doesn't? How much is too little? When are students most likely to be engaged? Does teaching about ethics influence ethical practice? How do you define and how do you measure learning outcomes in the ethics of physics? The information contained in this talk will be original but largely anecdotal, not unlike engaging ethics in the physics curriculum.

column5: Multimedia PreLectures in a Freshman Physics Bridging Course: Instructional Changes
column15: Gary Gladding, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
column18: This talk (part I of II) will summarize our recent instructional changes to Physics 100, a half-semester course designed to prepare entering engineering freshmen for introductory university physics. The course targets a subpopulation of students with low probabilities for success in introductory physics, as determined by demographic factors and performance on a diagnostic task. One major change has been the introduction of web-based animated multimedia presentations ("PreLectures") for the initial presentation of the material. We have also reduced the small group discussion sessions from two hours to one hour to allow for the addition of a clicker-based interactive lecture dealing with conceptual difficulties found in post-PreLecture online assessments.

column5: Physics at a Distance: Toward Certification of High School Physics Teachers in Tennessee
column15: Erica P Johnson, University of Tennessee
column18: Despite having in excess of 310 public high schools in the state of Tennessee, fewer than 200 statewide offered instruction in physics in the 2007-2008 acedemic year, and many of those courses were taught by teachers not accredited in physics. Assisting high school teachers in obtaining certification is imperative to the progression of physics education and is the goal of our distance learning program at The University of Tennessee. The goal is to offer a professional development program designed to help physics teachers aquire the content knowledge and pedagogical skills deemed important for them to help their students to acquire scientific inquiry skills, develop conceptual understanding of essential physics concepts and to develop a positive attitude toward physics. Currently, we are serving two Fentress County schools through a distance education program. Notable effects are evident in the cooperating teachers' understanding and progress toward obtaining certification. Details of the program will be presented.

column5: Development of a Research-Based Astronomy Lab Curriculum
column15: Jon M. Saken, Appalachian State University
column18: Physics and Astronomy education research has firmly established that students develop a better understanding of science when they can conduct investigations resembling actual research. Unfortunately, it is particularly difficult to offer introductory observational astronomy labs with the same degree of rigor found in other undergraduate science labs due to lack of individual equipment, uncertain weather, and long setup times of bulky equipment. Currently in its first full year online, ASU's GoTo Astronomy Facility addresses these difficulties by providing 16 computer-controlled telescopes with CCDs permanently mounted under a roll-off roof, requiring minimal setup. Students can make their own observations, even in marginal weather. To complement this state-of-the-art facility, a new research-based lab curriculum is being developed. This paper discusses student results and unexpected lessons learned by both students and instructors from one such lab: Determining the Mass of Jupiter via Kepler's Third Law.

column5: A "Quick Guide" to Redesigned Introductory Lab Activities
column15: Patricia E. Allen, Appalachian State University
column17: John E Cockman, Jon M Saken
column18: In an effort to redesign introductory lab activities to be more inquiry-based and less cookbook, a series of "Quick Guides" have been developed. These online documents are short tutorials on laboratory-related topics. These include: physics concepts, using probes and sensors, and data collection, analysis, and reporting. Each guide includes a short series of activities to assist students in developing requisite lab skills. Specific goals and content coverage for each lab meeting are achieved by selecting activities from two or three Quick Guides. For example, an exploration of springs may include activities from each of the "Force Probe," "Springs and Spring Energy," and "Graphing with LoggerPro" Quick Guides. A major advantage of the Quick Guides is the ability to tailor activities for a particular course (algebra- versus calculus-based), or even a particular section of the course. Additional benefits, plus some examples of Quick Guides will be presented and discussed.

column5: Online ILD with video materials
column15: Cheng Ting, Houston Community College System, Southeast
column18: Online activities for introductory physics have been developed for a hybrid course at HCCS, which spend half class time in classrooms and half class time online. The activities are derived from ILD, interactive lecture demonstration, of the activity-based physics. Adapting ILD in the learning environment software, BlackBoard, encourages more participation in interaction of teaching and learning. Other video materials like personal camcorder records, or Livephoto website are other resources to be used. The topics of torques, instantaneous center of rotation for a perfect rolling, and rigid body equilibrium are used for the online activities, so that the advanced questions can be discussed in classrooms.

column5: Writing to Comprehend and Inspire in Introductory Astronomy Laboratories
column15: Matthew P Wiesner, Northern Illinois University
column18: Among the primary goals of introductory astronomy courses are that students really understand the fundamental principles of astronomy and astrophysics and that they be sufficiently interested by astronomy to pursue lifelong learning int this discipline. This paper describes how writing was used to help to achieve these goals. Writing to learn is a very powerful pedagogical tool, and has been used widely in many of the sciences, especially in physics. In an introductory astronomy course, students were asked to complete several different types of writing tasks, including brief writing assignments associated with each lab report. These writing experiences helped students to think much more deeply about the content than they would if only completing lab worksheets and calculations, and encouraged them to interact more fully with astronomy.

column2: Best Practices for Teaching With Technology
column5: Inexpensive Quantitative Analysis of Resonance
column15: Timothy J. Moran, Chicago Public Schools
column18: A Barton's Pendulums setup is a great way to illustrate the power of resonance. When several pendulums are driven at at an identical frequency, only the pendulum with a matching resonance frequency moves through large swings. Here an inexpensive example of a Barton's Pendulums setup incorporating a DC motor is described and analyzed quantitatively. Graphing the results illustrates the resonance effect very clearly.

column5: Modifying our conceptualization of "framing"
column18: The concept 'framing' (how individuals interpret the kind of activity going on) is used in the physics education research community to make sense of observed variations in student reasoning and behaviors (i.e. Hammer et al., 2005). Much of this work argues many students frame physics classes unproductively; hence instructors should help students re-frame classroom activity. We agree with this view but are concerned framing is inadequately conceptualized. When used in sociolinguistics research framing is commonly characterized as happening simultaneously at a variety of nested levels. No one in the PER community uses framing this way, but there are advantages to it. First we will present analysis of "think aloud" data from students taking physics class-style quizzes to demonstrate some advantages. Then we will identify drawbacks with the current use of framing in the PER literature.

column5: Modifying our conceptualization of "framing"
column18: The concept 'framing' (how individuals interpret the kind of activity going on) is used in the physics education research community to make sense of observed variations in student reasoning and behaviors (i.e. Hammer et al., 2005). Much of this work argues many students frame physics classes unproductively; hence instructors should help students re-frame classroom activity. We agree with this view but are concerned framing is inadequately conceptualized. When used in sociolinguistics research framing is commonly characterized as happening simultaneously at a variety of nested levels. No one in the PER community uses framing this way, but there are advantages to it. First we will present analysis of 'think aloud' data from students taking physics class-style quizzes to demonstrate some advantages. Then we will identify drawbacks with the current use of framing in the PER literature.

column2: High School Pedagogies Based on Physics Education Research
column5: Formative Assessment in Secondary School Physics -- Turning Research into Practice
column15: Stanley J Sobolewski, Indiana University of Pennsylvania
column18: The literature is replete with research on the effectiveness of student- centered learning. Most physics teacher-candidates have a stock understanding of how effective these teaching strategies can be. They can recite literature findings showing the effectiveness of peer tutoring, formative assessment, and inquiry-based learning. However, when the teacher-candidate starts practice teaching, the deluge of necessary tasks can be overwhelming, resulting in a "teach as I was taught" strategy-- primarily didactic in approach. This technique feels successful, so it becomes a permanent part of the new teacher's instructional strategies. Practice teachers need to be given specific and concrete techniques of formative assessment. Various specific strategies that make formative assessment easy to implement will be discussed.

column5: The Home Energy Audit class project
column15: Richard E Flarend, Penn State Altoona
column18: As part of an Energy and Environment course, all students are required to do an energy audit of their home. Students collect and analyze utility bills and fill out a questionnaire about their home. This information is entered into a customized Excel spreadsheet that considers space heating, water heating, and water consumption. Improvements to their home can be simulated with drop down selection bars and the energy and economic savings are immediately shown along with the estimated cost to make the improvement. Students finish by identifying the most cost-effective improvements and submitting an audit summary.

column5: Traditional or Interactive-Engagement Physics: Toward a "Half-Way" Solution
column15: Juan A Chediak, California Baptist University
column18: Lecture-based physics instruction, the standard for decades, has come under critique in some circles. The claim is that high retention of physics learning requires interactive or inquiry-based methods including brief summaries (15-20 minutes) rather than more didactic presentations. However, some students note that pure inquiry-based pedagogy can result in teachers "never" providing answers: the professors Socratic method results in weaker students failing to achieve a confident understanding. The author attempted a half-way solution in a lower-division mechanics class: three 50-minute lectures were supplemented with a once/week three-hour inquiry-based, conceptually-intensive, tutorial exercise in a particular concept of mechanics. Homework was assigned to correspond with both the lecture and the tutorial component of the course. The former consists mainly of problems with quantitative solutions, the latter of conceptual exercises which replicated the tutorials previously conducted. Assessment was conducted using the force concept inventory and an average normalized gain of 64% was achieved.

column2: Physics Education Research in High Schools
column5: Gauging Student Understanding of Scientific Justification in an Astronomy Context (1)
column15: Sbastien Cormier, City College New York
column18: We investigated student understanding of what it means to provide a scientific justification. Students in a summer astronomy course at City College New York were asked questions within the domain of astronomy where they had to provide scientific justification in explaining their answers. We will describe the creation, refinement, and application of a rubric designed to infer student beliefs from their responses to these questions. The rubric analysis, along with teacher evaluations of student performance provide insight into the effects of instruction on student beliefs about science.
column19: (1) Supported in Part by the National Science Foundation

column2: Making the Transition from Introductory to Upper-Level Courses
column5: Importance of Introductory Physics Courses in Teaching Modern Physics
column15: Mitra Shojania Feizabadi, Seton Hall University
column18: Although many topics in modern physics appear abstract and new to students, they are linked to concepts in introductory physics. This talk explores and stresses the links between modern and introductory physics courses. This talk proposes that significant emphasis on introductory physics courses is desirable to establish the requisite foundation for subsequent studies in modern physics. A thorough understanding of basic principles of classical physics will serve the students well in their efforts to better understand modern concepts in this field.

column5: Optics Studio: Interactive Engagement in an Upper Level Physics Course
column15: Christopher M Sorensen, Kansas State University
column18: A variety of interactive engagement models have been used at the introductory level including the New Studio developed here at Kansas State University [1]. In this paper we describe an interactive course in Optics at the junior-senior-first year graduate student level. Interactive engagement is achieved by incorporating lab exercises, "lab-demos," performed by the students integrated within the lecture. Lab-demos are short, hands-on activities that have both experimental and demonstrational components [1]. A key aspect of our Optics Studio is the close temporal connection between the lecture and the lab-demos. Examples of the 46 lab-demos will be given as well as assessment of the relative educational progress made by our students.
column19: 1. C.M. Sorensen, et al., Am. J. Phys. 74, 1077-1082 (2006).

column5: The Longest Day: A Geometrical Calculation
column15: Timothy A Heumier, Azusa Pacific University
column18: Using just the fact that the Earth's axis is tilted at 23.5 degrees relative to its orbital plane and the rotation period is 24 hours, we can calculate how long the longest day will be at a given latitude. The calculation begins with drawings of the geometry at the solstice with compass, ruler and protractor, with only a couple of simple calculations needed at the end. Comparison with tabulated sunrise and sunset times on the solstice date follows. Careful students typically get within a few percent of the length of the longest day.

column5: Mystery of light bulbs: why half the current isn't half as bright
column15: Timothy A Heumier, Azusa Pacific University
column18: A puzzle presents itself during a routine exploratory circuits lab: Three identical flashlight bulbs are arranged so two are in parallel, with this combination in series with a third. The current in each of the parallel bulbs is half the current in the series bulb, yet the parallel bulbs may not even glow, whereas the series bulb does glow, albeit not as brightly as if it were alone in the circuit. This means that half the current does not result in half the brightness. An explanation includes how the blackbody radiation curve shifts with temperature and how resistivity is temperature dependent. The fraction of electrical power that is radiated into the visible part of the spectrum is a strong function of temperature. Measurements of brightness as a function of current are compared to theoretical calculations, with qualitatively good agreement.

column5: College Teaching and the Development of Reasoning, the Book
column15: Robert G Fuller, University of Nebraska Lincoln
column17: Thomas C Campbell, Dewey I Dykstra, Jr, Scott M Stevens
column18: Part of the foundation for the research in physics education house of physics is the work of Robert Karplus and Arnold Arons in the 1970s. They expressed a strong concern about conceptual understanding and mature reasoning by students. Karplus led a team of AAPT members to produce a workshop, Physics Teaching and the Development of Reasoning that was published by the AAPT in booklet form in 1975. That work was broadened to include other college disciplines and was offered on many campuses for faculty development activities for more than a decade. This book, with the AAPT booklet in Appendix B, brings together those broader materials along with new chapters to show how today's interest in interactive learning is based up this earlier work of Karplus and his interest in the work of Jean Piaget. The poster will provide additional information about the book and a prepublication flyer.
column19: 1 This book will be the first title in the new series, Science & Engineering Education Sources, Calvin S. Kalman, Editor-in-Chief, by Information Age Publishing, Inc. of Charlotte, NC. It is to be published in the summer of 2009. 2 In addition to the book editors named above, the book will be informed by advice from Arnold A. Strassenburg and Lesler G. Paldy, of SUNY, Stony Brook, who helped with the original AAPT version and from Dean Zollman, Kansas State University and Anton E. Lawson, Arizona State University.

column5: Studying Insulin Secreting Cells in Zebrafish (Behavioral Science)
column15: Fatimal Askia, Daniel Hale Williams Prep
column18: The specific aim of this project is to characterize a novel transgenic line of zebrafish that will better the understanding of beta-cell function in zebrafish. Procedure: 1) Collect embryos from the zebrafish. 2) Inject embryos at one cell stage with DNA construct but make sure you leave at least 15 uninjected embryos for your controls. 3) Hydrate larvae (wash in 60% MeOH, 5 min.; 30% MeOH, 5 min.; PBTx, 4 x 5 min.) 4) Transfer to a small plastic dish with PBTx; cut off tail (into yolk extension). 5) Wash in H20, 5 min., then transfer to glass tubes. 6) Incubate in ice cold acetone, 30 min. @ -20 degrees C. 7) Wash in H20, 5 min. 8) Wash PBTx, 3 x 5 min. 9) Block 1 hr., room temperature. 10) Primary antibody: dilute in PBS. Incubate overnight, 4 degrees C (or for 23 hr. at room temperature). 11) Wash 8 x 10 min., in PBTx-DMSO. 12) Secondary antibody: dilute in PBS. Incubate overnight, 4 degrees C (or for 23 hr. at room temperature). 13) Wash 8 x 10 min. in PBTx-DMSO. 14) Transfer to 80% glycerol solution for mounting. Conclusion: After completing this project, the hypothesis thus far has been supported. The CpepGFP trangene is only expressed in beta-cells and is properly targeted to insulin secretory granules, suggesting that the GFP tag does not interfere with processing. Currently data is being analyzed to see if CpepGFP is properly processed by Western blot analysis.

column5: Keep It Cool (Physics)
column15: Suad Causevic, Lane Tech College Prep
column18: The purpose of this experiment was to design a cooling system for high-density microprocessors using a magnetohydrodynamic drive. Procedure: After the design of the cooling system was complete, final checks and renderings were performed to ensure that its components were accurate and consisted of no defects. A model magnetohydrodynamic drive (using salt water) was then developed to test the mathematical and theoretical backbone of magnetohydrodynamics. Neodymium magnets were placed under an array of tubing. Aluminum electrodes were also placed perpendicular to the magnets on the interior walls of the tubing. The top layer of the tubing was then cut off, allowing the process of magnetohydrodynamics to be clearly seen. Conclusion: It was concluded from the data observed throughout the experiment that a magnetohydrodynamic cooling system could work more efficiently to transfer thermal energy from a microprocessor than current cooling systems. A cooling system is only as good as the heat capacity of the substance it uses for heat dispersion. If operational (using equations and labs), the magnetohydrodynamic cooling system could work more efficiently because the substances it could use to transfer heat (liquid metals, liquid semiconductors, ionized bases, and aqueous substances) have a much higher heat capacity than current cooling substances.

column5: Surface Tension (Chemistry)
column18: The purpose of my project was to find out what surface tension is and what the process wasalso if it can be broken. Another question is if a water strider will break the surface tension and sink at some concentration of detergent. Procedure: 1) Obtain 6-10 water striders (catch by nearby streams or purchase from biological supply companies). 2) Prepare the following serial dilutions of 1 molar SDS: .001m, .002m, .003m, .004m, .005m and distilled water (control) in 1000ml beakers. 3) Measure the relative surface tension for each detergent concentration. 4) Multiple trials are needed for each detergent concentration 5) Other factors such as temperature and pressure that can influence surface tension should be kept constant during observations and collection of data. Conclusion: My conclusion was detergent pollution at very low concentration of 0.005M is sufficient to prevent water striders from standing on the water surface.

column5: Does the Nature of Material Affect Resistance? (Earth Science)
column18: The purpose of this experiment is to study how and why sandbags are effective, by varying the material inside the sandbags. Procedure: 1) Position the water table, and place the sandbag in the middle of the water table. 2) Pour 6 liters of water on the left side of the sandbag. 3) Wait for the water to travel to the other side of the sandbag. 4) Record the amount of water on the right side of the sandbag every 20 seconds. Conclusion: The hypothesis that water displacement was least using sand was supported. Sand doesnt absorb/permeate any water. Not much water can pass through sand grains. The density of sand is much higher. The hypothesis that water displacement was most using coarse gravel was also supported. Coarse gravel permeates a large quantity of water. The size of gravel grains was substantially higher than soils grains. The density of coarse gravel is much lower than sand.

column5: The Effects of Acid Rain on Bean Plants (Botany)
column15: Mark Sikorski, Daniel Hale Williams Prep
column18: The project deals with the impact of acid rain pH and bean plant growth. Procedure: Part 1: Making Solution 1) Label six different plastic bottles, giving one for each 100% distilled, 100% sulfuric acid, 10% of solution, 1% of solution, 0.1% of solution, 0.01% of solution. 2) Pour 100 mL of distilled water into the bottle labeled 100% distilled water. 3) Pour 100 mL of sulfuric acid into the bottle labeled 100% sulfuric acid. 4) Pour 1 mL of sulfuric acid into the bottle labeled 10% of solution, place 99 mL of distilled water into the 10% bottle. 5) Continue to take 1 mL of last solution and 99 mL of distilled water into the next solution bottle. Part 2: Applying Solution/Germination 1) Label each Ziploc bag with a proper label giving each bag a solution and six different bags for each type of bean. 2) With cotton balls apply 10 mL of solution. There should be at least two cotton balls in each bag with a total of five beans in each bag. Part 3: Planting 1) Label 8 oz. cups, so that there is one cup for every solution and six cups for every type of bean. 2) Place enough soil to fill to the brim of the cup. 3) Put the five seeds from the bag into the properly labeled cup. The seeds should be a knuckles distance from the top. Part 4: Place cups near window. Conclusion: In this experiment, the hypothesis was supported. The plants fed with 100% sulfuric acid didnt sprout. The plants fed 100% distilled water didnt do the best, however they did do better than the 10% and 1% dilutions. The acid rain impacted the bean plants negatively. With the high levels of pH on the bean plants, some of them didnt sprout. As the pH went down, the bean plants had a better chance of surviving.

column5: The Stroop Effect (Behavioral Science)
column18: The purpose of this project is to investigate the Stroop Effect in thought processes using the terms of interference, perception, attention, naming, and colors. It is easier to correctly identify a word if the word is printed in the same color. The opposite result occurs when the color word does not match the ink color (i.e., the word red is printed in green ink), due to the Stroop Effect. Procedure: Obtain 20 sequences of five color words printed in matching color ink for page one. For page two, use color words printed in a different ink color from the word. Group one volunteers were instructed to call out the ink color of each word of the matching set (words printed in the same ink color) and were timed. Group one then completed the same process with the nonmatching words (words printed in different ink colors). Group two completed the same process but in the reverse order (nonmatching first, matching second). The time averages and differences were calculated for both. Conclusion: It took all subjects longer to complete the nonmatching color words. It was difficult for subjects to fight the urge to say the ink color instead of the word.

column2: Chicago Public Schools Student Science Fair
column5: Chicago Science Fair High School Presentations
column18: The Chicago Public Schools Student Science Fair is in its 59th Year of operation; this years theme is Shaping Our Future, Through Science and Mathematics. Each year thousands of CPS students DO science by performing a Science Fair Project in various disciplinary areas, and it is then presented at their classroom and/or school fair. The best of these get to bring their projects to one of the 24 Area Science Fairs, and about 500 of these get to participate in the Citywide Science Fair. CPS Science Fair students have earned numerous awards at the Illinois State Science Fair (IJAS), and even at the International Science Fair (ISEF). Many of the past participants in CPS Science Fair have not only received awards and scholarships for their research, but have gone on to study in the various STEM disciplines and have gone on to successful STEM careers. Today we present high school student projects from across the city, students who have participated at least in their area fair, and most of whom have been or will be presenting at the Citywide Fair at the Museum of Science and Industry in March. Please feel free to discuss their research with them and offer your suggestions. In addition to the abstracts below, the following high school students are also expected to participate: Rudy Alfaro (Lane Tech College Prep); Barbara Banda (Curie Metropolitan H.S.), Ground-Level Ozone (Environmental Science); Edith Flores (Hubbard), Calorimetry and Light Bulbs (Physics); Terrence George (Lincoln Park H.S.), Imaging Mitochondrial Ca2+ dynamics in B Cells (Biochemistry); Faraz Khan; Nicole Kuklinski (Lane Tech College Prep), Effects of Electromagnetism on Plants (Physics); Theodore Zajler (Lane Tech College Prep) (Botany); and Erick Zuniga (Curie Metropolitan HS), Band Gap (Chemistry). * CPS Student Science Fair is support by the Chicago Public Schools, by numerous corporate sponsors, including Motorola, ComEd, BP, and the Museum of Science and Industry, and by a host of volunteers. More information about CPS Student Science Fair may be found at www.cssf.org.

column5: Writing and peer review for advanced laboratories: a proposal
column18: There are a number of significant goals and issues associated with the teaching of advanced laboratories. Faculty teaching advanced laboratories often experience a feeling of isolation. For students, the laboratory is a critical tool for synthesis of the physics knowledge which can be challenging to achieve. Our proposed solution to these seemingly dissimilar issues is a new paradigm for the advanced laboratory that encourages the students to write scientifically, includes calibrated peer reviews, and crosses school boundaries to create a shared mission for faculty. When students write a paper, they submit the article to the journal for review. A reviewer may be a faculty member or another student at another institution. Some of the articles students receive will be calibration articles written by faculty, some will be by students at other institutions. Through this process faculty and students will form communities and students will engage in writing about physics.

column5: The Brazil Nut Effect in Microgravity
column15: Andrew Vanden Heuvel, The Prairie School
column17: Terah Hennick, Alex Janiuk, Alex Meyer
column18: The Brazil Nut Effect (BNE) is the well-known experiment where large grains, when agitated, rise to the top of a container full of smaller grains. Out of the many variables that impact the motion of a large intruder in the BNE, gravity is undoubtedly one of the most important. It is also the most difficult to manipulate. We had the opportunity to participate in a zero gravity flight through the Northrup-Grumman Weightless Flights of Discovery Program. We designed a mobile apparatus to test the efficiency of the BNE in the absence of gravity. Surprisingly, we discovered that under microgravity conditions the Reverse Brazil Nut Effect is established. Furthermore, we found that the rise and fall times of the intruder were not significantly impacted by the absence of gravity.

column5: The Use of Clicker Questions in the Teaching of Introductory Optics
column15: R. Seth Smith, Francis Marion University
column18: Clicker questions were developed for optics presentations for Francis Marion University's introductory physics class in the fall of 2008. The clicker questions were embedded inside Power Point presentations by using Turning Point software. Students in the class responded to these questions by using radio frequency devices known as clickers. The effectiveness of this approach at engaging students in class and confronting misconceptions pertaining to optics will be discussed. A comparison to traditional chalk and blackboard methods will be presented. Specific examples of clicker questions, student materials, and classroom activities will be shown.
column19: My AAPT sponser is Larry Engelhardt (member # = 84281).

column5: Visualization and Simulation Capabilities on Modern Computing Hardware
column15: Tad Thurston, Oklahoma City Community College
column18: The pace of floating point and graphics computing hardware has, arguably, progressed much faster than physics-simulation software packages designed to take advantage of them. A number of physical situations (Schrodinger solver, N-body particle simulator, spring systems) are simulated in real time along with an interactive visualization of the simulation to estimate rough upper bounds on what can be accomplished in terms of frame rates, polygons rendered, simulation time step and spatial resolution densities, as well as how to estimate the inevitable trade-offs between simulation and visualization calculations. The computing framework uses a compiled language (C++) and the OpenGL (3-D) library.

column5: Theory, Design, and Application of a Raman Spectroscopy System
column15: Laura A Merrill, Appalachian State University
column18: Raman spectroscopy measures changes in vibrational energies of molecules. It is based on the Raman Effect, a phenomenon in which light is inelastically scattered from a molecule and experiences a change in frequency due to the transfer of energy to or from that molecule. The energy difference between the incident and scattered light is characteristic of the vibrational or rotational energy of the molecule. The authors designed and built a Raman spectroscopy system capable of studying inorganic materials that has successfully detected a Raman signal. A schematic of this Raman system will be presented, as well as an explanation of the system component configuration. Recent developments in Raman Spectroscopy have led to new applications ranging from materials characterization to medical diagnosis.

column5: Common Misconceptions about Nuclear Energy and Radioactivity
column18: This presentation describes common misconceptions that students have on nuclear reactors and radioactivity. These misconceptions are often similar to those held by the general public. Unfortunately such erroneous perceptions often dominate the discussion in public debates about the use, dangers and benefits of nuclear energy and radioactivity. Here is a sample of some of theses misconceptions. 1. Nuclear reactors can explode like atom bombs. 2. Radioactivity is synonymous only with death. 3. Only nuclear reactors can produce nuclear waste. 4. The best way to dispose of nuclear waste is to launch it into space. 5. When food is irradiated with gamma rays it becomes radioactive. 6. Humans must strive for radioactivity-free living conditions. The author will outline the specific details of these misconceptions and elaborate on the methods he uses to discover and correct them.

column5: A controlled investigation of student learning in the SCALE-UP environment.
column17: Mark Constas, Julia Kregenow, Matt Price, Michael Rogers
column18: The Physics Education Research Group at Ithaca College is actively engaged in a multi-year study of student learning in the "SCALE-UP" environment. This study is being conducted in both general-education astronomy and introductory algebra-based physics courses. Student learning is being probed using written pre- and post-tests as well as interviews and reflection logs. Written questions include standard multiple-choice diagnostic instruments, open-ended conceptual questions targeting known student difficulties, and surveys concerning the nature of science. Students chosen to form a representative sample of the class are participating in interviews and writing reflection logs at predetermined times during the course. Some interviews will focus on content while others have focused on the nature of science, epistemological issues, and structural issues in the classroom. Preliminary results will be presented.
column19: Funded in part by NSF DUE CCLI grant # 0536246 and Ithaca College.

column5: Transforming Introductory Astronomy in the Urban University
column17: Mel Sabella, Lynn Cominsky, Kevin McLin
column18: The physics and astronomy program at Chicago State University (CSU) has adopted an instructional environment that embraces inquiry-based instruction, research on student learning, and instructional revision. Building upon successes in our introductory physics courses, we have expanded our efforts to include the introductory general education astronomy course at CSU. Working with the Education and Public Outreach group at Sonoma State University, we have developed and implemented several new inquiry-based lab activities that build upon more traditional verification labs. We have also implemented research-based materials such as Lecture Tutorials and Mastering Astronomy in the revised course. Student researchers have created open-ended assessment questions for each of the lab activities and have aided in course instruction. We describe our implementation, as well as the successes and challenges we face.

column5: Estimating Thunderstorm Generator Currents
column17: Thomas C Marshall, Maribeth Stolzenburg, Christopher R Maggio
column18: A technique has been devised to estimate from observations the thunderstorm generator current, an important parameter for the global electric circuit as well as a measure of the strength of in-cloud charging mechanisms. For one cell the method indicates that during a three-minute time interval the in-cloud charge generation produced an average current of about 0.4 A. Similar analysis in another developing thunderstorm cell with a short lifespan indicates that the early generator current was as large as 0.14 A, but it decreased by a factor of about three as the cell began to dissipate and merge with another cell less than 7 min later. This presentation will describe the method and results, and then compare the estimated generator currents to other estimates of the various currents flowing in the thunderstorm environment.

column5: Southern Arizona STEM Internship Program
column17: Julia K Olsen, Julia K Olsen, Julia K Olsen, Julia K Olsen
column18: Southern Arizona STEM Internship Program is a partnership between the University of Arizona Colleges of Education and Science, Southern Arizona Leadership Council (SALC), Tucson Regional Economic Opportunities (TREO), public school districts and charter schools, and science and technology industries and businesses. The purpose of the center is to provide professional development, internships, and networking both to increase the retention of science and math teachers and to improve science and math teaching and learning. The center features an intensive internship program aimed at a select group of beginning teachers. The internship program includes features that are essential for successful retention of new teachers. It is long-term, combines the best practices of teaching and learning with the expertise of the business and research community, creates a community of practice that will support teachers, and helps classroom teachers build their expertise in content and delivery of science, math and technology skills within the 21st Century Skills Framework.

column5: Undergraduate Research Experiences with the Global Telescope Network
column17: Kim Coble, Nicole Broughton, Katy Wyman, Lynn Cominsky
column18: Students at Chicago State University and Sonoma State University have undertaken observational programs using telescopes of the Global Telescope Network (GTN) and SkyNet. The GTN is a network of small telescopes funded by GLAST to support the science of high-energy astrophysics missions. It is managed by the NASA E/PO Group at Sonoma State. SkyNet encompasses a network of telescopes managed from the University of North Carolina to catch gamma ray burst afterglows. A primary motivator behind both networks is education. In this program, undergraduates schedule, reduce and analyze observations of active galaxies and other targets. Students then present their work as part of observational course work, or in some cases as a "capstone" research experience required for graduation. This work gives students direct experience with several aspects of scientific research, including literature searches, data acquisition and analysis, and reporting of results.

column2: Best Practices for Teaching With Technology
column5: Analyze That! -- How High School Students Attack Cosmic Ray Data
column18: How can 42 high school students participate in the analysis of a science experiment? Last June two classrooms participated in a pilot program to cooperatively analyze cosmic ray data from the MARIACHI cosmic ray experiment. The scientific goal was to investigate the sensitivity of the experiment to terrestrial magnetic field disturbances caused by solar flares, in particular from a weak event that happened in late April. Each student was responsible for one segment of data, and used Excel to retrieve and manipulate cosmic ray data as well as weather data. The students determined the barometric pressure dependence of the cosmic ray data, which they subtracted before graphing the resulting cosmic ray rates during the time of the event to look for rate enhancement or suppression.

column5: The bouncing ball in the context of a geometrical series
column17: Juan Chavez, Maria Gonzalez, Jose Barron, Juan Luna
column18: The mathematical representation of a bouncing ball on the floor is a difficult topic for many students of the introductory mechanics courses. The research group named Physics and Mathematics in Context from the University of Juarez in Mexico has developed a learning proposal to improve the relationship among several representations of the bouncing ball situation. The idea in this case is to associate the physical properties of the bouncing ball real representation to a geometrical series. The cognitive development proposal is based on the students' understanding through this geometrical series that shows the time the ball lasts to stop bouncing. In addition, we show the ratio of two consecutive heights during the corresponding bouncing motion, and the comparison of the calculation and measurement of the time the ball lasts to stop.

column5: Demonstrations of physics concepts through physical and mathematical contexts
column17: Maria Gonzalez, Jesus Estrada, Fernando Estrada, Angel Hernandez
column18: Most students in introductory physics courses have difficulty understanding the necessary physical concepts to have success with their engineering studies. Some of them have difficulties learning and using the cognitive tools during the development of a formal scientific knowledge. In this sense, the research group from the University of Juarez named Physics and Mathematics in Context presents a learning proposal through the interaction between the real and mathematical representations of physical concepts. This proposal is based on in-class demonstrations to allow students meaningful understanding.

column5: Video experiments, ISLE cycle and thinking like a physicist
column18: The PER group at Rutgers University had developed a number of physics videos aimed to effectively implement video technology through ISLE cycles (Etkina, Van Heuvelen, 2006), recommended to be used concurrently with The Active Physics Learning Guide (Pearson, 2006). A second intent of the physics videos is to provide a resource of ideas and methods for constructivist physics teaching, to teach students to think like physicists (Van Heuvelen, 1991). The videos are produced by real people using common laboratory equipment and they are carefully classified into qualitative and quantitative observation experiments, qualitative and quantitative testing experiments, and the application experiments. The poster will inform the audience about the existence of these teaching tools and will invite the teachers to use them in all high school level physics courses; introductory-level physics college courses, as well as physics (and science) methods courses for pre-service physics (science) teachers.

column5: What not to do with Mom's Microwave: SPS Outreach Program
column15: London D Jenks, Brigham Young University - Idaho
column18: Looking for an exciting and uncommon SPS outreach program? This outreach program utilized a series of demonstrations that include a discussion of a microwave's basic function and its ordinarily unexplored applications as well as demonstrations presenting principles of thermodynamics and pressure. These demonstrations are aimed at physics students, nonphysics majors, secondary and elementary students and children of all ages. Used to encourage physics majors to join the Society of Physics Students and encourage nonphysics majors to recognize physics in their every day lives, this program helped to promote the study of science amongst elementary and secondary students.

column5: Lessons in Learning: Concepts, Reasoning and Epistemology in Introductory Courses
column15: London D Jenks, Brigham Young University - Idaho
column18: Original research in introductory physics courses provides a look at what most influences students' learning: gender, year, math level, and beliefs about learning. Using the Force Concept Inventory (FCI), Epistemological Beliefs Assessment for Physics Science (EBAPS), and the Lawson Test of Scientific Reasoning knowledge is gained about how students feel about learning physics, how courses influence reasoning ability, and how demographics influence learning.

column2: Computation in Undergraduate Physics: New Developments
column5: Computational Physics Projects in a General Physics Course
column18: This poster describes the computational physics projects implemented in a calculus-based general physics course at the presenter's institution. The projects are designed to help students visualize concepts that are beyond the scope of the textbook material and to enhance their understanding of the course subjects through computer modeling and simulation. Several examples are described in detail. One example is the simulation of a single-slit diffraction, in which students perform the simulation based on the underlying physics-- the Huygens's Principle and the interference of point sources. Details on how these computational projects are implemented, such as how much computer programming is required from the students, what computing environment is used, and how these projects fit into the class schedule, will be discussed. The educational values of these projects will also be analyzed.

column5: PER in Polynesia: How much does culture matter?
column18: I spent the last semester teaching at BYU-Hawaii in Laie, Oahu, among one of the most diverse student bodies in America. Cross-correlating student responses to surveys, including the FCI or CSEM, the Lawson test, and the EBAPS, I hoped to see if cultural differences would affect interactive engagement efforts. Although we're just analyzing the data at the time of the abstract deadline, my anecdotal experiences yield some very interesting conclusions.

column5: Results of an experimental, inquiry-based physics lab
column15: John E Cockman, Appalachian State University
column18: Students of a traditional physics lecture and a modeling-based physics class were mixed together in two sections of an experimental, inquiry-based lab and four sections of a traditional, cookbook lab. Over the course of one semester, these various combinations of lab and lecture were evaluated using video analysis, student interviews, an internal survey, the CLASS (Colorado Learning Attitudes about Science Survey), quizzes and exams, student evaluations, and a departmental diagnostic tool based on the FCI (Force Concept Inventory). Preliminary findings indicate that students in the experimental lab sections outperformed those in the traditional lab sections, with the combination of the modeling-based physics class and the inquiry-based lab being most beneficial.

column5: Using Wii Experiment for kinematics in the laboratory or classroom
column15: M. L. Horner, Southern Illinois University Edwardsville
column17: Thomas Duncan, Heather Lynch, Andrew Martin, Scott Miller
column18: The remote for the Wii gaming platform is a readily available, convenient, relatively inexpensive accelerometer and infrared detector that connects physics with students' lives outside the classroom. WiiExperiment is open-source, cross-platform software which provides a physics-oriented interface to the Wii remote's data. The technology and its limitations will be discussed in the context of physics demonstrations and laboratory experiments.

column2: Assessment of Effectiveness of Educational Technologies in Instruction
column5: Application of the Mobile Studio IOBoard in an Introductory Physics Course
column15: Peter D Persans, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute
column17: Stephanie Tomasulo, Gwo-Ching Wang, Donald L Millard
column18: We report on the use of the Rensselaer Mobile Studio IOBoard (www.mobilestudio.rpi.edu) and associated software in an introductory electromagnetism and waves course. The IOBoard connects to the user's PC via USB, providing an inexpensive multipurpose instrument. We utilized oscilloscope, audio output, and function generator capabilities of the card. During fall 2008, the Studio Physics approach was used to teach 12 sections of about 48 students each. Most students in one of those sections purchased an IOBoard and performed experimental activities that were revised to extend outside the classroom. For example, students explored the properties of an RC circuit as an ac voltage divider in class and the properties of an RL circuit outside of class on their own. We will describe and demonstrate specific experimental activities, student response, and preliminary analysis of student performance on test questions that address mastery of associated topics. Funded in part by the NSF.

column5: Increasing numbers of Physics Teachers by Crafting a Professional Teacher
column15: Stanley J Sobolewski, Indiana University of Pennsylvania
column18: During the past few semesters, activities in teacher training have been developed to enhance recruitment and retention in the physics teacher education program. This presentation examines the characteristics of pre-service physics teachers, pointing out some of the student-perceived discrepancies in the program. Alumni and upper-level students have brought out these incongruities through interviews. Over the course of several semesters, advising sessions have been initiated to address these discrepancies. Instruction in the content course does not follow the "pedagogical paradigm" put forth by the college of education. No formative evaluation and little student-centered instruction takes place in these classes. This results in confusion for the teacher candidates; the institution seems to have a "do as we say, not as we do" policy. Other measures such as a NOS survey and the FCI are being gathered in order to identify potential pre-service teachers.

column2: Nuclear and Particle Physics in the Upper-Level Curriculum
column5: Discovering the Quantum Universe
column15: Marcela Cerena, Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory
column18: Particle physics is on the verge of important discoveries that will address some of the most fundamental questions of science: -- The origin of mass of the elementary particles -- The unification of all the forces, including gravity -- The explanation of the matter-antimatter imbalance of the Universe -- The origin of Dark Matter and Dark Energy I will show ongoing and near future collider experiments, using the Tevatron at Fermilab and The Large Hadron Collider at CERN, that will re-shape our understanding of the Universe.

column2: Frontiers in Space Science and Astronomy
column5: Our Miserable Future
column15: Lawrence M Krauss, Arizona State University
column18: In this talk, I will ruminate on the future of the universe itself, and also on the future of life within it, using as my starting point recent observations in cosmology. I will first discuss why the universe we appear to inhabit is the worst of all possible universes, as far as considerations of the quality and quantity of life is concerned. I will then address several fascinating questions that have arisen as a result of our discovery that the dominant energy of the universe resides in empty space.

column5: How Can We Keep and Advance More Women in Physics
column18: To strengthen the economy, maintain national security, improve the environment, etc., it is vital that the United States maintain a strong science and technology workforce, including physics. Complicating the situation is the fact that white male interest in engineering and the physical sciences has been declining over the last three decades and the nation is expected to face major demographic changes. To maintain the S&T; workforce, the United States and other nations must increase the participation of women and underrepresented minorities. This, in turn, requires that department chairs and others in positions of authority to actively encourage their participation. Success will require that there be, and be perceived to be, gender equity in the S&T; community. Recommendations of the American Physical Society Gender Equity Conference and the International Conference on Women in Physics will be presented.

column2: AAPT Plenary II - Exciting Research at Fermilab
column5: Exciting Neutrino Physics at Fermilab
column15: Niki Saoulidou, Wilson Fellow, Fermilab PPD/Neutrino
column18: I will discuss the fascinating neutrino story from "birth" to "observation" with emphasis on the phenomenon of neutrino oscillations. Then, I will focus on the tremendous knowledge gained in the past decade from neutrino oscillation experiments worldwide. Finally, I will focus on the remaining open questions in neutrino physics, their importance, and the strategy we develop to address them with near- and long-term neutrino oscillation experiments at Fermilab.

column5: Rotating Galaxies and Dark Matter
column18: From the time of the earliest humans to the present, each civilization has told stories about the universe. How we understand the universe is dictated in large measure by the available technology. In the last century, we learned that we inhabit a galaxy of 200 billion stars, that the universe is populated by billions of galaxies, and that galaxies are moving away from each other. Equally important, we now understand that everything evolves: stars are born, evolve, and die; galaxies grow at the expense of their neighbors. I will describe the evidence that the stars, galaxies and clusters of galaxies that populate the universe make up less than 5% of its matter. The remaining matter is dark, and is only detected by its gravitational effect on the bright matter we study. While virtually everything we know about the universe we have learned in the 20th century, still more remains unknown.

column2: Using Research to Guide Science Teacher Professional Preparation
column5: A Brief History of Research on Preparation of Physics Teachers
column18: Implementation of practical and effective preparation of qualified physics teachers has been a central concern of national policymakers and scientific leaders for more than 50 years. A wide variety of methods have been used and large amounts of resources have been expended on this task. However, to date, there has been relatively little systematic research by disciplinary experts directed at probing the key features of this problem. I will review some of the history of past practices and offer a synopsis of past and present research investigations that bear on the issue.
column19: *Supported in part by APS and AAPT through PhysTEC: NSF PHY-0108787.

column5: Using Kinematics to Teach Doppler Shift
column18: Most students in their first physics course find the general Doppler shift formulas confusing despite the abundant and relatively subtle role of the velocity of the source. Most students are inclined to conclude the relative speed between the observer and the vehicle is what determines the change in pitch. We propose a kinematics problem that allows the students to discover for themselves the general Doppler shift formula and allows them to gain a better understanding of the relationships between frequency, wavelength, and speed of traveling sinusoidal waves.
column19: Anthony Reynolds, Embry Riddle Aeronautical University

column5: The History and Fate of the Universe
column18: Using our most advanced techniques and instruments, we sift through relic clues and evidence to understand the events surrounding the birth and subsequent development of the universe. A precision inspection and investigation of the Cosmic Scene, along with careful analysis, discussion, and computer modeling, have allowed us to determine what happened over billions of years with amazing certainty and accuracy. Some of the findings are surprising and show shocking twists of plots. There remain even more mysteries to be solved. In spite of that, we can tell the tale of the creation and history of the universe, and show key supporting evidence, some from very early times, to provide a direct image of the embryo universe.

column5: Physics for Animation Artists
column18: The Animation/Illustration Program at San Jose State University is based in the School of Art and Design. It is consistently ranked as one of the premier animation programs in the nation and, because SJSU is located in the heart of Silicon Valley, many graduates go on to work at local studios and companies such as Dreamworks, Pixar, ILM, and Electronic Arts. The authors will describe their experiences in team-teaching an upper-division animation course and the curriculum materials developed for teaching physics (primarily mechanics) to art majors. [Supported by an NSF/CCLI grant]

column5: Physics Labs with Flavor (developing Recurrent Studies methodology)
column15: Mikhail M Agrest, College of Charleston
column18: The methodology of recurrent studies in the practice of teaching introductory physics labs and in studio-style teaching brings flavor into the learning process. It passes on the spirit of research into the teaching/learning process, as it includes prediction of the results of experiments based on modeling and examination of the process and gives students a chance of direct and immediate application of the acquired knowledge [1]. Providing visual and immediate assessmentn it enhances learning. The quality of the performance of the experiment tremendously affects the results. Inaccuracy in measurements and in the performance of the procedure leads to inaccurate predictions followed by the doubts of the modeling of the process and affects the evaluation of students' work. This presentation will include detailed description how to apply the method to new topics. Recommendations on application of the recurrent method to topics suggested by the participants will be developed and discussed.
column19: 1. Mikhail M. Agrest, Physics Labs with Flavor or The Recurrent Method of Learning of Phenomena in Physics Labs. The Physics Teacher, 2009 accepted for publication.

column5: What Influence the Interests of Girls for Physics?
column18: The present talk presents some findings, examples of best practice and recommendations resulting from the workshop "Attracting girls to physics" organized as part of the International Conference on Women in Physics, Seoul in 2008. Young people in general want to work with something worthwhile and fulfilling. What this means depends on the culture and social development on their country. How does the interest in physics fit in this picture? Several studies have addressed the question about what it is about physics that makes girls turn away. "Prototypical" physics, envisioned as difficult, hierarchical and objective, is commonly reproduced in classrooms thus undermining the more inclusive physics.The workshop was an excellent opportunity to identify best practices, worldwide. It was agreed that the image of science in general is formed at an early age. For this reason enabling outreach activities to schoolchildren, both girls and boys, including young children, is a key element and new, successful outreach projects to children below the age of 11 years were reported by several countries. The experiences and the expectations will be discussed.

column5: Project W.I.S.E. -- Building Youth-Program Partnerships that Serve the Community
column15: Gregory A. DiLisi, John Carroll University
column18: We describe the design and implementation of our Project W.I.S.E. partnership, a multi-institutional collaboration that assembles interdisciplinary teams of high school students charged with developing STEM-focused community youth-programs. Our goal is twofold: (1) to promote young women's interest in STEM-oriented careers through an early, positive exposure to informal science education, and (2) to trial-test a model of how high schools can collaborate with universities and informal learning centers to build strong, successful youth-program partnerships that serve the local community. Our project is innovative in its youth-development strategies, the targeting plan for diverse audiences, and the focus on women's contributions to aviation and space flight. The project also gives high school students rare but powerful opportunities to contribute directly to the quality of life in their community and to work in multi-disciplinary, multi-generational teams.

column2: Best Practices for Teaching With Technology
column5: 10 Ways to Engage your Students with Innovative Technology
column18: Whether you moodle, google, or doodle, technology is an essential part of developing engaging lessons. This poster presentation demonstrates a variety of innovative methods that are being developed into an online physics curriculum (www.sciencewithmrnoon.com). Some of the lessons that will be highlighted on this poster presentation include creating web-based presentations, Flash animations, video webcasting, interactive quizzes, live web conferencing, virtual simulations, online discussions, webquests, and classroom response systems (clickers).

column5: A Web Crawling Tour of ScienceWithMrNoon.com
column18: For the past five years, Brendan Noon has been developing a large variety of free physics web resources on www.sciencewithmrnoon.com including, audio notes, self-assessing web quizzes, virtual simulations, streaming video presentations, printable classroom activities, STEM projects, physics jeopardy powerpoints, and even interactive cartoon animations. Stop by this presentation and discover the many ways to use this multifaceted web resource to engage students in your physics classroom. More about this presentation can be seen via streaming video at: http://www.sciencewithmrnoon.com/tech01.htm

column2: Making the Transition from Introductory to Upper-Level Courses
column5: An old but effective technique
column15: Bruce R Boller, Washington and Lee University
column18: Typically, physics majors take an intermediate course in mechanics in the sophomore year. Several months usually have elapsed since the students have thought about physics much less having agonized over the solutions to problems. The "Newtonian Mechanics" course at Washington and Lee University provides an ideal setting to bridge the gap between the introductory physics course and upper-level courses. It is here that student behavior is gradually molded into professional behavior. The routine outlined in red italics below is quite effective for class sizes that are moderate such as up to perhaps 12 students or so. Sample in-class getting-started problems are presented.

column2: Making the Transition from Introductory to Upper-Level Courses
column5: An actual level of difficulty of test problems and its subjective perception by students.
column18: Developing tests (midterms and finals) is an important part of a job every instructor has to do. The transition from introductory to upper-level courses is difficult sometimes because of a significant increase in the difficulty of tests. Should a test be easy or difficult; how do we measure the difficulty of the test; how do students decide if a test was difficult--should faculty even ask these questions? The assessment process is very subjective, but it is a fundamental part of teaching, since, in a way, it shows how good we are at it. To bridge our understanding of what should be assessed and how, we conducted a survey asking students to evaluate how difficult the test problems were from their point of view and comparing the students' responses with (a) an average grade for each problem (shows its actual difficulty), and (b) instructor's opinion. Preliminary analysis shows that students' evaluation of the difficulty of a test problem, as well as provided by faculty, often does not correlate with the actual difficulty level. The poster provides related data.

column5: Particle Phenomenology of Gravitational Events at the TeV Scale
column15: Arunava Roy, The University of Mississippi
column18: We show how to differentiate the minimal supersymmetric extension of the standard model (SUSY) from black hole events at the CERN Large Hadron Collider. Black holes are simulated with the CATFISH generator. Supersymmetry simulations use a combination of PYTHIA and ISAJET. Our study, based on event-shape variables, visible and missing momenta, and analysis of dilepton events, demonstrates that supersymmetry and black hole events at the LHC can be easily discriminated. We also discuss how to differentiate BH and string resonances at the LHC.

column5: Estimations of Electrical Conductivity Above Thunderstorms
column18: Electrical conductivity is a fundamental parameter of the upper atmosphere, but it is difficult to measure directly. Many lightning flashes produce transient increases in the electric field (E) above their parent thundercloud. These E transients can be measured with sensors carried above the thundercloud by balloons. In this presentation we combine balloon E data, Lightning Mapping Array data, and radar data to estimate the conductivity above several active small thunderstorms. This paper reports the observation of variations in the electrical conductivity over thunderstorms made in the altitude range from 8 to 13 km for eight Intra Cloud (IC) flashes from three different days in July and August 1999. Our results indicate that conductivity ranges 1.70 x 10^{-13} S/m to 3.20 x10^{-13} S/m over the thunderstorm for our data. Our results are in good agreement with [Holzworth et al., 1991].

column5: Polymer Electrolyte Membrane Fuel Cell with Aligned Carbon Nanotube Electrode
column17: Gabriel Goenaga, Junbing Yang, Di-Jia Liu
column18: Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have been considered a promising material for various applications. Electro-catalyst support for polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) is one of them. There have been a number of reports on CNT-based membrane electrode assembly (MEA) in PEMFC, but CNTs in these electrodes are oriented randomly and the advantages associated with the structural properties of CNTs were not fully utilized. We report here our progress in fabricating and evaluating MEA made of catalyst decorated, vertically aligned carbon nanotube (ACNT) layers. For comparison, a commercial MEA prepared through the ink-based process was also tested under similar conditions. Improved performance was observed for ACNT-based MEA, particularly at high current region, suggesting enhancement in mass transport and improved water management.
column19: This work was supported by the U.S. Department of Energy, Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy.

column5: Development of Newton's Laws of Motion: Discovery or Invention? Discovery or Invention?
column18: A review of the history of Newton's Laws of Motion illustrates the artificial and socialized nature of science knowledge, reflecting the notions of sociocultural views, as well as cognitive and rational endeavors for achieving logical consistency and conceptual coherence, in congruence with the notions of constructivist views. The reflection of both constructivist and sociocultural views challenges the domination of positivist and transmissive commitments reflected by conventional teaching. Three stages of the historical development are discussed, i.e., prior to the Principia, the 3rd (last) edition of the Principia, and the modern view. The congruence between the historical development and sociocultural views implies that providing sophisticated instruction and engaging students in social interaction/participation are both essential for learners to become familiar with the artificial tools and the ontological and epistemological assumptions of these tools. However, the demand of individual cognition is not overlooked, to achieve better clarification, precision and coherence in students' conceptual understanding.

column2: Best Practices for Teaching With Technology
column5: Using an on-line homework tutorial system in the High School Classroom
column18: I will present my experiences with using the Mastering Physics program in my Advanced Physics class. Mastering Physics is an online tutorial system where students do homework as well as concept learning activities. I will tell how I used this system and what my students think about it. While there are a few minor problems with it, my students and I are enthusiastic about it. It has enabled me to teach more physics content and to teach it better by giving students extra practice in doing problems, giving them hints when they are stuck, and saving me from having to go over all the homework problems in class.

column2: Best Practices in Recruiting and Retaining Women and Minorities in Physics
column5: Five Steps to Successful Physics Recruitment and Retention
column15: Daryao S Khatri, University of the District of Columbia
column18: Entering college freshmen, in increasing numbers in practically every public institution of higher learning are in need of one or two remedial math courses. This is particularly a big problem at the Historically Black Colleges and Universities, where a large number of remedial math course sections are offered to meet the growing demand. For most of these students, graduation is delayed by at least a year. In addition, these students continue to be taught by teaching methodologies that did not work for them even in high schools, resulting in disgust and hatred for math. This situation makes entry for these students into STEM areas difficult and is the perfect recipe for failure in STEM disciplines if they enroll in college-level courses. Because of this situation, recruiting and retaining majors in physics has become a major problem for the physics community.
